data.title: Things You Need to Know [Part One]
data.meta_description: Read Things You Need to Know [Part One] from the story The Gothvale School District Variety Show Story by CoriAlston19944 (Cori Alston) with 31 reads. love, fr...
data.text:
Celia Cruz:

Úrsula Hilaria Celia de la Caridad Cruz Alfonso, also known by her stage name, Celia Cruz was an Afro Cuban singer who was born on October 21, 1925 in Havana, Cuba. Celia was and is the prominent and influential female figure of Salsa music, who was best known for her colorful costumes, wigs, and her catchphrase, 'Azúcar,' which means sugar in Spanish. Celia was a member of La Sonora from 1950 to 1965 and Fania All Stars in the 70s and 80s. Her career spanned for 55 years, earning her hits like, Quimbara, La Vida Es Un Carnaval, La Negra Tiene Tumbao, Rie Y Llora, Yo Vivire, Guantanamera, Azucar Negra, Tu Voz, Toro Mata, and the cover of Tito Puente's Oye Como Va until she passed away on July 16, 2003 from brain cancer at the age of 77 years old. Her music influenced so many artists including, Marc Anthony and Gloria Esteban. Also, there is a 80 part telenovela series about the singer's journey of life and career titled, Celia, which you can find the series on Netflix.

La Lupe:

Lupe Victoria Yolí Raymond aka La Lupe was a Cuban singer, who was significantly notable as the Queen of Latin Soul, singing boleros, guarachas, and Latin Soul along with her energetic and sometimes controversial performances. Born in the barrio of San Pedrito in Santiago de Cuba on December 23, 1939, she participated in a radio program which allowed fans to imitate their favorite celebrities and one day, she escaped from school to sing Olga Guillot's song, Miénteme (Lie to Me), winning the competition. She admired Celia Cruz and Olga Guillot. In the sixties, she became the most acclaimed Latin singer when she was partnered with Tito Puente.
